answers.answer: Perhaps one of three things comes to mind:  Migraine headaches with aura, hypoglycemia (like diabetes), or seizure activity.  Visiting your regular doc and having them check your blood sugars would be a good first step.  If your sugars are okay, then a neurologist can make a determination about whether you have seizures or not by running an EEG tape.  If you don't have seizures, then the neuro can also decide if it's indeed migraines or even some other neurological or brain problem that I'm not familiar with.While you wait to see your doc, carry some sugar candy around with you, and when this feeling begins to come over you, eat it, and that way IF your blood sugars are low, you just might minimize or even stop the shaking and sleeping stuff.  And obviously you should not drive or be around dangerous mechanical things until this thing is sorted out.  Some people who exercise via a sporting activity will get the sort of thing you're talking about, but usually their eyes are involved, and if I'm not mistaken, most of those things are indeed low blood sugars.

question: From time to time, and at various times of the day, I get a feeling of being "spaced out" then within seconds, I can not walk or talk and after making it to my chair, both arms and legs begin to shake violently and almost instantly I get a severe headache where the brain connects to the spinal cord. The headaches are unbearable. I place ice packs on the back of my neck and that does seem to help. Also, the violent shaking will last from about 5 to 20 minutes and sometimes will alternate between my right side and left side. After the shaking stops, I fall into a very deep sleep. Any thoughts?
title: Violent shaking and headaches
